explanation:
Agent A is correct. In MHD_connection_handle_write the code computes
  const size_t wb_ready = connection->write_buffer_append_offset
                          - connection->write_buffer_send_offset;
and immediately calls MHD_send_hdr_and_body_(connection,
                                           &connection->write_buffer[connection->write_buffer_send_offset],
                                           wb_ready, ...);
There is no prior runtime check that (a) connection->write_buffer is non-NULL, (b) connection->write_buffer_send_offset is within the allocated buffer, or (c) connection->write_buffer_append_offset >= connection->write_buffer_send_offset. The code relies only on mhd_assert to document the invariant (append_offset >= send_offset). Since asserts can be compiled out, the subtraction can underflow (producing a very large wb_ready) and/or the pointer expression can be out-of-bounds. Any use of that pointer/length inside MHD_send_hdr_and_body_ (which very likely uses memcpy/other <string.h> functions) could therefore access beyond the bounds of the referenced object. That is exactly what MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 forbids. Without additional guaranteed checks (either here or proven in the callee) the code is non-compliant with Rule 21.17.
